results.title: Charmes de l'existence (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Films De Saint-Germain-Des-Pres, Jean Gremillon and Pierre Kast
results.brief_description: French language only. The French Academy is the supreme arbiter of what is often referred to as “official art”, art that paints a surface reality but is in fact the embodiment of those morals, ideas and virtues that have received official sanction. In this film official art has been used to satire the social history of France at the turn of the century - the fashions, foibles, conventions, the glory of battle and triumph of virtue. Utilising canvases of painters who won the Prix de Rome between 1860 to 1914, the film follows the Seven Ages of Man, presenting the official view of a way of life. Award: International Prize for a Short Feature, Venice Film Festival, 1950.

results.title: Charm school
results.brief_description: An animated films about two pompous ladies sitting down for a cup of tea and one boasts of her fortunes and properties while a crunch bird remarks “fantastic”. No other credits available. A comedy.

results.title: Charm school
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Brian Adams
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
Another in the series following the development of Australian art and artists. Robert Hughes discusses the work of Russell Drysdale, Donald Friend, Jean Bellette, Paul Haeflinger, David Strachan, William Dobell, Justin O’Brien, Sali Herman, Lloyd Rees, and Geoffrey Smart. Written and narrated by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Charly
results.creator_credit: Selmur Productions, Robertson and Associates and Ralph Nelson
results.brief_description: Charly Gordon (Cliff Robertson) is a gentle adult with the mind of a child. His determination to improve attracts the attention of his nightschool teacher, Alice (Claire Bloom). Charly exists in a world bound by his room and his job as a bakery sweep. Alice persuades a clinic to help Charly and the doctors agree to use him as a subject for experimental neuro-surgery. The operation is successful. Charly’s mind develops and he learns quickly, but his emotional growth does not keep pace. He appears before a convention as living proof of the surgery results and brilliantly answers questions. However, shortly before his appearance, he makes a frightening discovery; and the film ends with an unexpected resolution. Co-starring Lilia Skala, Leon Janney, Ruth White and Richard Van Patton. Cliff Robertson won an Oscar for his performance, a role he first tackled on TV’s U.S. Steel Hour in 1961. Based on the novel “Flowers for Algernon” by Daniel Keyes.

results.title: Charlotte's web (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Hanna-Barbera Productions, Sagittarius Productions, Joseph Barbera, William Hanna, Charles Nichols and Iwao Takamoto
results.brief_description: Lovable farmyard characters from E. B. White’s novel cavort, sing and explore their world. Wilbur the pig is afraid he’ll end up on the dinner table, until he is befriended by Charlotte the spider and saved by her magic web. Voices include Debbie Reynolds, Henry Gibson and Agnes Moorehead.

results.title: Charlie needs a cloak
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Charlie is a shepherd. He has a cosy house, a big hat, a crook, a flock of fat sheep - and a tattered cloak. In the springtime, Charlie decides to make himself a new red cloak. He shears his sheep and fashions his new garment from the wool. This animated film, sparked by a whimsical Italian tarantella musical score, follows the process of making woollen cloth into clothing with charm and wry humour. The conclusion will delight - and not altogether surprise - the young viewer. Written and animated by Tomie de Paola from his book of the same name.

results.brief_description: In the “Fireman”, Charlie Chaplin stars as a lazy and inefficient fireman.(1916). Also features “Caught in a Cabaret” (1914). Rated: G

results.title: Charlie Chaplin: The Adventurer/the Cure
results.brief_description: Charles Chaplin was born on April 6, 1889 in South London of not so successful music hall entertainers. At the age of eight he joined a variety act called “The Eight Lancashire Lads” and worked all over England and parts of Europe throughout his childhood. He toured America in 1910-11 and returned to that country again in 1912 to 1913 where he was seen by Mack Sennett and joined the Keystone company for $150 per week. This cassette features: “The Cure” (1917) and “The Adventurer” (1917).

results.title: Charlie Chaplin. Vol. 03
results.brief_description: This compilation video features four of Charlie Chaplin’s short films. “Easy street”: Charlie becomes a policeman and imposes his own brand of order on chaotic Easy Street. “The Immigrant”: Charlie meets a beautiful girl on board a ship. After many hilarious hardships they rescue each other and live happily ever after. “The Cure”: Our hero deposits the contents of his liquor bottle into the curative spa at a Sanatorium. “The Adventurer”: The hectic experiences of an escaped convict, with Charlie starring as the convict.
